messages.content: You are tasked with creating a structured output from the provided user message.

Here is the mapping for the user-related endpoints under the cms blueprint, including the full request paths, and per-method acceptability derived from the code.

How paths are composed
- The cms blueprint is mounted at /cms (registered in app/__init__.py).
- The user blueprint inside cms is mounted at /user (registered in app/api/cms/__init__.py).
- Each route in app/api/cms/user.py is relative to /cms/user.

Full HTTP request paths (no path parameters in these routes)
- /cms/user/register
  - Methods allowed (from code): POST
- /cms/user/login
  - Methods allowed (from code): POST
- /cms/user
  - Methods allowed (from code): PUT
- /cms/user/change_password
  - Methods allowed (from code): PUT
- /cms/user/information
  - Methods allowed (from code): GET
- /cms/user/refresh
  - Methods allowed (from code): GET
- /cms/user/permissions
  - Methods allowed (from code): GET
- /cms/user/captcha
  - Methods allowed (from code): GET, POST

Method-by-method acceptability (based strictly on the code)
- HEAD
  - /cms/user/register: False
  - /cms/user/login: False
  - /cms/user: False
  - /cms/user/change_password: False
  - /cms/user/information: True
  - /cms/user/refresh: True
  - /cms/user/permissions: True
  - /cms/user/captcha: True
- GET
  - /cms/user/register: False
  - /cms/user/login: False
  - /cms/user: False
  - /cms/user/change_password: False
  - /cms/user/information: True
  - /cms/user/refresh: True
  - /cms/user/permissions: True
  - /cms/user/captcha: True
- POST
  - /cms/user/register: True
  - /cms/user/login: True
  - /cms/user: False
  - /cms/user/change_password: False
  - /cms/user/information: False
  - /cms/user/refresh: False
  - /cms/user/permissions: False
  - /cms/user/captcha: True
- PUT
  - /cms/user/register: False
  - /cms/user/login: False
  - /cms/user: True
  - /cms/user/change_password: True
  - /cms/user/information: False
  - /cms/user/refresh: False
  - /cms/user/permissions: False
  - /cms/user/captcha: False
- DELETE
  - All listed endpoints: False
- PATCH
  - All listed endpoints: False
- OPTIONS
  - All listed endpoints: True (Flask provides OPTIONS support for routes; this aligns with Flask behavior rather than an explicit decorator in your code)
- TRACE
  - All listed endpoints: False (no TRACE in the route definitions)

All-methods-acceptable indicator
- None of these endpoints accept all HTTP methods. So “all methods acceptable” is False for every listed endpoint.

Explanation
- The actual paths come from the blueprint composition:
  - CMS blueprint is mounted at /cms.
  - User blueprint inside CMS is mounted at /user.
  - Each function in app/api/cms/user.py is mapped to a specific subpath (register, login, empty string for the base /user path, change_password, information, refresh, permissions, captcha).
- There are no path parameters in these routes (no {param} placeholders).
- Acceptable methods are strictly what is declared in the @user_api.route(...) decorators:
  - register: methods=["POST"]
  - login: methods=["POST"]
  - "" (the base path /user): methods=["PUT"]
  - /change_password: methods=["PUT"]
  - /information: default is GET (since no methods arg provided)
  - /refresh: default is GET
  - /permissions: default is GET
  - /captcha: methods=["GET","POST"]
- HEAD/GET/PUT/POST/DELETE/etc. behavior for each endpoint is deduced from Flask behavior in relation to the declared allowed methods:
  - HEAD is effectively allowed only if GET is allowed; otherwise not. Since only GET-enabled endpoints show HEAD as True, others are False.
  - OPTIONS is generally always supported by Flask (hence True for all endpoints).
  - TRACE is not defined in code (False for all).
- The explanation above is strictly based on the code, not on typical API design expectations.

If you want, I can present this as a concise OpenAPI-ready summary with each path and its allowed methods explicitly listed.
